canonical_explanation.text: Compound Interest is the interest calculated on both the principal amount and the accumulated interest from previous periods. Unlike simple interest where interest is calculated only on the principal, compound interest grows exponentially as the interest earned in each period is added to the principal for calculating interest in the next period. The compound interest formula is A = P(1 + r/100)^n, where A is the amount, P is the principal, r is the rate of interest per annum, and n is the time period. For different compounding frequencies, the formula is modified: for half-yearly compounding use A = P(1 + r/200)^(2n), and for quarterly compounding use A = P(1 + r/400)^(4n). The compound interest (CI) is calculated as CI = A - P.
rules: Compound interest is always greater than or equal to simple interest for the same principal, rate, and time period
The difference between CI and SI increases as the time period increases
For yearly compounding: A = P(1 + r/100)^n
For half-yearly compounding: A = P(1 + r/200)^(2n), where n is in years
For quarterly compounding: A = P(1 + r/400)^(4n), where n is in years
When compounding frequency increases, the compound interest increases
For inverse problems, substitute known values and solve for the unknown variable

questions.question_text: If Rs 1000 is invested at 10% per annum compound interest for 2 years, what will be the amount after the first year?
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) Rs 1100. After the first year, the amount would be the principal of Rs 1000 plus the interest earned at 10% per annum, which is Rs 100. Therefore, the amount after the first year is Rs 1000 + Rs 100 = Rs 1100.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are: A) Rs 1000 - This is just the original principal amount and does not account for any interest earned. C) Rs 1200 - This is the final amount after 2 years, not after the first year. D) Rs 1210 - This is also the final amount after 2 years, not after the first year.

questions.question_text: When calculating compound interest year-by-year, the interest earned in the first year is added to the _______ to find the principal for the second year.
questions.explanation_correct: The interest earned in the first year is added to the principal (the original amount) to find the principal for the second year. This is the essence of compound interest - the interest earned in each period is added to the principal, so that the next period's interest is calculated on a larger amount.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The interest earned in the first year is not added to the interest, but to the principal amount. The principal is the starting amount on which interest is calculated in the first year. For the second year, the principal becomes the original principal plus the interest earned in the first year, and the interest is calculated on this new, higher principal.
